description: From Latin vulgātus, past participle of vulgō (“publish, make common, cheapen”).

adjectives.description: vulgate (comparative more vulgate, superlative most vulgate)

entries.meaning: (archaic) Made common, published for common use, vulgarized.
(of a text, especially the Bible, not comparable) In or pertaining to the common version or edition.
The vernacular language of a people.
examples: The linguistic and socio-historical evidence herein examined suggests that the development of Coptic occurred in Ptolemaic Egypt, not only as a spoken vulgate in the Delta, but as a script produced through  […]

entries.meaning: (of a text, especially the Bible) A common version or edition.

verbs.description: vulgate (third-person singular simple present vulgates, present participle vulgating, simple past and past participle vulgated)

entries.meaning: To publish, spread, promulgate to the people.
